title: The Compromise of 1850
subtitle: Delaying the Inevitable (1850)

sections.title: Crisis Over Slavery
sections.summary: I'm Anna, fifteen, living in San Francisco. The California Gold Rush has transformed our territory overnight. In 1848, when gold was discovered at Sutter's Mill, California had maybe 14,000 non-Native residents.

sections.title: Clay's Compromise
sections.summary: Henry Clay, now 73 and in failing health, proposes one last compromise to save the Union. He's brokered compromises before—the Missouri Compromise in 1820, the Tariff Compromise in 1833. He's called the "Great Compromiser," though critics say he just postpones inevitable conflicts.

sections.title: The Fugitive Slave Act
sections.summary: After months of debate, the Compromise passes in September 1850. California is admitted as the thirty-first state, a free state! We celebrate in San Francisco with parades, speeches, and fireworks.

sections.title: Popular Sovereignty's Flaw
sections.summary: The compromise's popular sovereignty provision sounds democratic—let settlers decide slavery for themselves. But it's morally bankrupt. Whether human beings can be enslaved shouldn't be decided by majority vote.

sections.title: Temporary Peace
sections.summary: The Compromise of 1850 brings temporary calm. Tensions ease. Talk of secession fades.

key_facts: The California Gold Rush has transformed our territory overnight.
Henry Clay, now 73 and in failing health, proposes one last compromise to save the Union.
After months of debate, the Compromise passes in September 1850.
The compromise's popular sovereignty provision sounds democratic—let settlers decide slavery for themselves.
Many Americans are relieved that catastrophe was averted.
